&bibliography; ranking Ranking
PROBLEM: Arrange a set of items in order of importance
RELATED - Ranking (a rank-ordered list of items = a permutation of items) - Rating (a numerical score assigned to each item)
Any rating scheme can be used to produce a ranking list
EXAMPLES
- Web search: PageRank (Google) and HITS (Ask.com)... 10-30 links from millions of web pages containing some given words
- Product recommendation: Netflix, IMDb (Internet Movie Database), Amazon...
- Economics: United Nations HDI (Human Development Index), http://hdr.undp.org/en/statistics/ Index of Economic Freewdom (Heritage Foundation), http://www.heritage.org/index/
- Education: US News ranking of colleges and universities (http://www.usnews.com/rankings), Financial Times business school rankings (http://rankings.ft.com/businessschoolrankings/), The Times Higher Education Suplement ranking of World universities (http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/world-university-rankings/), the Academic Ranking of World Universities from the Shanghai Jiao Tong University a.k.a Shanghai ranking (http://www.arwu.org/), Webometrics ranking of the web presence of 20000 higher education institutions (http://www.webometrics.info/),
- Sports: BCS (Bowl Championship Series) ratings for college football teams (invitations to bowl games), RPI (Rating Percentage Index) for college basketball teams (invitations to the March Madness tournament), ATP World Tour ranking of tennis players, http://www.atpworldtour.com/Rankings/Singles.aspx FIDE chess ratings, http://ratings.fide.com/
- Politics, i.e. voting
Other domains: citation databases (scientific papers, patents, legal cases,...), social networks...
CAVEAT: Arrow's Impossibility Theorem
A perfect voting system does not exist
Incompatible requirements, from Kenneth Arrow's 1951 Ph.D. dissertation:
- Every voter ranks the candidates in the order he desires (unrestristed domain)
- If all voters prefer A over B, A should be ranked ahead of B (Pareto principle)
- When, within a subset of candidates, voters choose A over B, this relative order should be maintained over the whole set of candidates. Changes in the order of other candidates outside the subset should not affect the relative ranking of A and B (independence of irrelevant alternatives)
- No voter should have a disproportionate control over the election (non-dictatorship)
No voting system with three or more candidates can simultaneously satisfy these four (reasonable) criteria.
ranking-pagerank PageRank
++ Page et al. 1998 Brin and Page 1998
IDEA: The popularity of a web page is proportional to the number of times a web surfer would visit the page when randomly surfing the Web. Since the WWW is a directed network, random walks could be trapped into dead ends (out-components). Therefore, we must allow random restarts...
r_i = \frac{p}{n} + (1-p) \sum_{j: j \rightarrow i} \frac{r_j}{d_{out,j}}
where n is the size of the network, d_{out,j} is the out-degree of node j, and p is the probability that the web surfer jumps to a node chosen uniformly at random (claimed to be about 0.15).
Typically, the higher the number of incoming links, the higher the PageRank of a given page. In uncorrelated networks (i.e. without node-degree correlations), the PageRank value for a node with a given number of links can be computed as Fortunato et al. 2008
r(d_{in}, d_{out}) = \frac{p}{n} + \frac{1-p}{n} \frac{d_{in}}{\langle d_{in} \rangle}
++ Random walks and Markov chains... e.g. www.whydomath.com video describing PageRank teleportation, dangling nodes, and random surfers to a non-mathematical audience

++ Facebook has its own algorithm, EdgeRank, which (in conjunction with September’s addition, GraphRank) determines which items appear at the top of an individual's news feed. EdgeRank is based on many variables, including who Facebook thinks are a user's closest friends and how many people have interacted with a piece of content.
++ The social network's news feed sorting filter is called EdgeRank. It helps Facebook keep users updated on friends' activity without overwhelming them with every single post, "like," and comment spilling out of their social graph.
In 2010, *the company first provided public details on how it curates users' news feeds... The details are few, but what's known is that the EdgeRank formula is based on how Facebook judges the closeness of two people (or a person and a brand), how valuable an activity is (sharing a photo is better than clicking "like," for instance), and how long ago it took place. Precisely how these factors are measured is not revealed, and, like Google, Facebook is constantly making tweaks.

ranking-HITS HITS
++ Kleinberg 1998 Kleinberg 1999a Kleinberg 1999b
CITATION ANALYSIS: Top authorities are like influential research papers cited by many other papers. Top hubs correspond to relevant surveys citing many influential papers.
Sometimes, we might be interested in finding hubs and authorities within densely-linked collections (HITS returns just the major cluster corresponding to top-ranked hubs and authorities). These might correspond to non-principal eigenvectors, which can be computed using other numerical computing algorithms, such as orthogonal iteration or QR iteration. Examples: polysemic words, controversial issues (reflected as polarized groups within a network).
NOTE: Minor perturbations on the network can greatly influcence hub and authority scores, whereas they have little effect on PageRank scores
(ref. Ng, Zheng, Jordan: "Stable algorithms for link analysis", SIGIR'2001) introduced the random jump step of PageRank into HITS to improve its stability.
(ref. Lempel, Moran: "The stochastic approach for link-structure analysis (SALSA) and the TKC effect." Computer Networks 33(1-6):387-401, 2000 ) proposed SALSA, a stochastic algorithm for link structure analysis that combines PageRank and HITS features to improve authority and hub computation by using two Markov chains: one for hubs and a different one for authorities.

Multi-topic pages... (+ the problem of topic drifting, i.e. returning pages that have nothing to do with the topic search just because they are collected due to the presence of out-links that connect to them or even spamming in-links).
(ref. Chakrabarti: "Integrating the document object model with hyperlinks for enhanced topic distillation and information extraction" WWW'2001, 221-220) segments the page based on its DOM tree structure to identify the subtrees that are more related to a query topic.

This importance value is then used to weight the links in the HITS or PageRank computation, thus reducing the impract of unimportant links.

ranking-evaluation-kendall Kendall's tau
ref. Maurice Kendall: A new measure for rank correlation. Biometrika, 30, 1938
Kendall's \tau correlation measure:
\tau = \frac { n_c - n_d } { \binom{n}{2} }
where n_c is the number of concordant pairs and n_d is the number of discordant pairs. Since \binom{n}{2} = n(n-1)/2 is just the number of pairs of items in the list, -1 \leq \tau \leq 1.
Perfect agreement: \tau = 1
Perfect disagreement: \tau = -1
Computation: ref. Ronald Fagin, Ravi Kumar, D. Sivakumar: Comparing top k lists. ACM SIAM Symposium on Discrete Algorithms, 2003, 28-36
Variations for dealing with partial lists, lists of varying size, and lists containing ties ref. Cynthia Dwork, Ravi Kumar, Moni Naor, D. Sivakumar: Rank aggregation methods for the Web, WWW Conference, 2001 ref. Cynthia Dwork, Ravi Kumar, Moni Naor, D. Sivakumar: Rank aggregation revisited, CiteseerX ref. Ronald Fagin, Ravi Kumar, D. Sivakumar: Comparing top k lists. SIAM 17, 2003
e.g.
\tau_{partial} = \frac { n_c - n_d - n_u } { \binom{n}{2} - n_u }
where n is the number of unique items in all the lists under consideration (otherwise, we could not make pairwise comparisons of the resulting \tau_{partial} values) and n_u is the number of unlabeled pairs. Hence,
\frac { - \binom{n}{2} } { \binom{n}{2} - n_u } \leq \tau_{partial} \leq = \frac { \binom{n}{2} } { \binom{n}{2} - n_u }
Intuitive feature: \tau_{partial} penalizes disjoint partial lists more than reverse partial lists.
Drawback: Disagreements at the bottom of the list incur the same penalties that disagreements at the top (typically, errors at the bottom are less important)
ranking-evaluation-spearman Spearman's footrule
Charles Spearman
Spearman's measure weighs disagreements according to their position in the lists:
\rho = \| l - \tilde{l} \|_1 = \sum_{i=1}^n | l(i) - \tilde{l}(i)|
Taking the particular position within the ranked lists into account, we can define a weighted footrule measure Langville and Meyer 2012:
\rho_{weighted} = \sum_{i=1}^n \frac { | l(i) - \tilde{l}(i)| } { min \{ l(i), \tilde{l}(i)\} }
Extension to partial lists @ Langville and Meyer 2012, pages 207-209

Spectral ranking
Even though made famous by Google, eigenvalues and eigenvectors have been used in ranking techniques for more than 50 years. Collectively, such techniques are known as spectral ranking techniques.
ref. Sebastiano Vigna: Spectral Ranking, arXiv, December 2009, http://arxiv.org/abs/0912.0238/
Theory (origin): Study of nonnegative matrices by Oskar Perron (1880-1975) and Ferdinand George Frobenius (1849-1917). In fact, the unique largest eigenvalue of a real square matrix with positive entries and its corresponding eigenvector are also known as Perron value and Perron vector, respectively.
ref. Perron, Oskar (1907), "Zur Theorie der Matrices", Mathematische Annalen 64 (2): 248–263, doi:10.1007/BF01449896 ref. Frobenius, Georg (1912), "Ueber Matrizen aus nicht negativen Elementen", Sitzungsber. Königl. Preuss. Akad. Wiss.: 456–477
Practice (application to ranking): fundamental contributions of Seeley and Wei (the dominant eigenvector, possibly with stochastic normalisation), Katz (damping) and Hubbell (boundary condition)
